awd_titl_txt: Teleseismic Studies of the Snake River Plain (An Experiment to Determine Variations in Upper Mantle Properties beneath  the Eastern Snake River Plain)
awd_abstract_narration: 119628474  Humphreys    This research involves the completion of analysis of results from  the Snake River Plain, Idaho, project.  This project involved the  emplacement and recording of seismic data from 28 PASSCAL portable  seismic systems over a 10 month period in 1993-1994 to delineate  the upper mantle and crust of the Snake River Plain, a volcanic  feature that is the result of the passage of the Yellowstone Hot  Spot across the northwestern U.S.  The need for additional funds is  in part a result of the success of the experiment and the  acquisition of much more usable data than was anticipated because  of a high success rate for data recording and a high number of  usable seismic events during the recording interval.  The results  will bear on questions of what happens to upper mantle structure  and earthquake occurrence when a hot spot traverses through a  region of continental crust.  This research is a component of the  National Earthquake Hazard Reduction Program.  ***
